author: CANNAGAR_TOOLS

description.text:
This is my first contribution, made the model for a co-worker who requested it and thought I should put it up here and share it. I don't have a 3D printer so I won't make any suggestions on how to print this (rafts, fill, supports, etc).

This is designed to be printed with black, then an alternating lighter color, and black again so the "text" layers pop. There is a hollow area in the "head" of Mr. Shrugman to help conserve filament, and also provide some buoyancy should the need arise.

This was printed once at reduced scale (thanks to a friend with a new 3D printer and filament to burn), with supports, but was noted that the black supports discolored the lighter color on the face. So it may be a good idea to not print the first layer of black all the way up to the face of the object. This way, any supports that may be used would be the same color as the lighter layer where they touch the "face" of Mr. Shrugman. It could also be printed in one color and painted, or whatever, I don't know...

¯_(ツ)_/¯

Any tips are appreciated, and I will try to donate anything received to local animal welfare orgs. / shelters.
This was printed at reduced scale, probably about 1/3rd to 1/2 the original size ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

title: E3D Modular Mount for Anet A8

description.text:
This is a work-in-progress, there are a couple of things need fixing, and I haven't tested it on the printer yet.

It's a modular mount for E3D style hot ends. Currently only a single E3D can be mounted, but I plan on making a double mount soon. Slides can be removed/replaced, making it easy to swap hot ends.

There are dovetail rails on both sides for mounting fans, cameras, sensors etc, but I haven't designed anything to fit them yet.

Your comments would be greatly appreciated.

You can find all my Anet A8 upgrades here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/FredGenius/collections/anet-a8-upgrades

I also highly recommend this Front Frame Brace by Leo Nutz:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1857991

Presumably, you want the E3D holder to be as low-profile as possible to save weight so it's not going to be wide enough to clear the bearing. Starting to see where the conundrum is coming from. Four screws would be ideal for strength but not a lot of real estate in there for that without going wide.

Thanks to Prusa Resarch for the original design!

This is a modification of NeilMed's commercially available sinus rinse holder for their NeilMed sinus rinse. Like theirs, it can be mounted on a mirror (with suction cups) or wall (with drywall anchors). Unlike theirs, mine can also be used freestanding on a counter. Also unlike theirs, mine doesn't fall off the mirror every few days. The crenelated bottom allows for better drying on a countertop.
There are other designs on Thingiverse, but mine is the only tri-mode design.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Works fine with 20% infill, and saves ~2 meters filament. However, I prefer a stronger part for countertop use, because it will be cantilevered on the wall or mirror, and will be under stress when you're trying to pull it off the mirror (it's really secure). There is also no risk of sanding through the outer wall if you need to widen the neck of the bottle holder (see below). There are voids designed into the nozzle holder to minimize the amount of filament used.
Prints upside down without supports, but the bottle bowl is pretty messy and needs to be cleaned up. Adding supports may help. Slowing down the print or adjusting the temperature may also help. The nozzle holder keeps it from printing right side up, but could be fixed with supports or a remix.
Fits on the Monoprice Mini build plate (120x120mm) when rotated.

Finishing

Clean any large whiskers out of the bottle bowl. Test fit the bottle in the bowl. Using (in order of preference) a bastard file, sandpaper, or rotary tool, enlarge the neck of the bottle bowl to fit the neck of the rinse bottle. Some bottles don't fit by less than 1mm diameter. Printing 100% infill will ensure you don't accidentally go thru the outer shell. Finally, using sandpaper or a rotary tool, clean up some of the mess inside the bottle bowl.

Mounting

Uses three commonly available 20mm suction cups for mirror or shower mounting. They can be found on Amazon or in hobby and craft stores. You could get by with two and either deal with the slight tilt, or make a spacer to level it.
Uses two drywall screws to mount to a wall. Anchors are probably not necessary for this application. Check to make sure the screw head is the proper size for the keyway prior to installation.
Countertop usage is intuitively obvious.

title: Lid for DoogieLabs' CR-10S bowden drive with guide and filament sensing

description.text:
Printed as-is in Gembird PETG (Dutch manufacturer) at 235°C with 80°C heated bed, "Everyday" brand (generic) hairspray on a 300x300 mirror directly on top of the aluminium plate. 50 mm/s worked fine for me, YMMV. Has a 2° taper on the part that goes inside the sensor housing, and fits in just fine at 100% on my printer. It's not loose, but it is easy to remove, so you may want to oversize to 101% or 102% to make it a tighter fit.

The reason the actual extruder parts aren't shown in the picture is because, as you can see in the second picture, it's mounted directly above my hot end to turn the printer into a makeshift direct drive-alike. The reason it's not color coordinated is because I was testing different filaments and wasn't sure how well this would work yet.

description.text:
Kids love key chains. Why not make one out of the Pythagorean Theorem? The square piece here is about 45mm x 45mm x 5mm.

The two patterns are used frequently in visual mathematics (proof without words). It might have a Chinese origin. The big square minus the four right triangles is c^2 on one side and a^2+b^2 on the other side. So it visually proves the Pythagorean Theorem. It is easy to print. Please try a higher resolution for a smooth appearance. Have fun!

for Psychology

First, this is not supposed to be political, but you can make of it what you will, I don't care.

¯_(ツ)_/¯

This is the Shruggie or "Presidential Medal of Excellence" which is one of the highest honors of Nerdom, or so I have heard. When accepting the award it is considered respectful to say "I don't know what this is for" or some variation of that phrase as culturally appropriate, only then is it acceptable to applaud and congratulate the lucky recipient of the award.

This prestigious medal was designed to be printed in two colors with the text layer in black, and an alternating color scheme for the base. When deciding on the base color for the medal, it is customary to use the Star Trek uniform color scheme (from the original series of course - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Trek_uniforms#Star_Trek:_The_Original_Series). That is, use yellow or green for command staff (boss/manager), blue for science officers (general nerds) and red for the every one else's (interns). The medal does not need to be printed in genuine Starfleet velour, PLA is acceptable these days. Failure to adhere to the standard will void the award and probably result in a few eye rolls.

The final official medal should be 60 x 67 x 4 mm

Please note that I don't have a 3D printer, so I have not printed this version out. But I was able to get a similar version printed, and have corrected some issues from that print in this model (had some floating text that I fixed).
¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: saixo

print_settings.Notes:: since the globe is quite small at the bottom I chose to use rafts for my first print - it would be a shame if anything fell over after 30 hours of printing
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
2018-03-02 There is a new implementation of this object.

This is a python script to map a grayscale image as a height map onto the inside of a hollow sphere. The result is a spherical lithophane with a smooth outside.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm layer 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

100%

Notes:
  • since the globe is quite small at the bottom I chose to use rafts for my first print - it would be a shame if anything fell over after 30 hours of printing
  • you don't want to see any fill pattern shine through the walls and the whole concept of a lithophane depends on a solid wall
  • on the other hand don't forget that the globe itself is hollow - the 100% infill only affects the wall of the globe

Original idea

A couple of days ago I saw the YouTube video where RCLifeOn presented his spherical lithophane globe. He used Autodesk 3ds Max to design the object, where he placed the height map on the outside of the globe, but I immediately wondered how it would look like when the height map was hidden inside the globe.

I din't see before now that RCLifeOn also posted his globe here on Thingiverse.

Free and open source?

Not having access to this piece of software I researched if I could get a similar result using free tools. My favorite OpenSCAD does not (yet?) support mapping of bitmap files onto non-flat surfaces, so I had to look further.

I quickly found an example on how to create an .stl file in python and started to experiment. My first output was a simple cube, before I put all pieces together:

  • scaling an image
  • creating a sphere
  • creating a second sphere
  • putting the two spheres into each other
  • modifying the thickness of the wall by means of the map
It works

Once I got the orientation of the faces correct and also succeeded in putting the image data the correct way onto the spheres, I let my script run for an hour or so and created the mesh for a 120 mm diameter globe, which has now been on the printer for 24 hours with about 10 hours left to go according to Octoprint.

The map I use is the free height map image of the world by NASA.

I then took the time to fine tune the script a bit and add some comments for readability.

User parameters 
# user settings
dia          = 120
depth        = 3
wall         = 0.8
latsteps     = 600
longsteps    = 1200
openingNdeg  = 20    # opening x degrees from north pole 
openingSdeg  = 130   # opening x degrees from south pole
  • dia is the diameter of the final globe in mm
  • depth is the maximum variation of the thickness of the globe's wall
  • wall is the minimum remaining thickness of the wall
  • latsteps is the number of steps from north to south
  • longsteps is the number of steps along the equator
  • openingNdeg is the size of an optional opening at the north pole
  • openingSdeg is the size of an optional opening at the south pole

The above example settings produce a narrow rim of the globe between 40°N (=-90+130) and 70°N (=90-20) for testing purposes.

pre-rendered .stl files
  • lithophane_world_closed.stl complete world, 120mm diameter, no holes, 300 latitude steps, 600 longitude steps
  • lithophane_sphere_outside low-resolution, mapped on the outside of the sphere
Work in progress
  • 2018-01-24 started printing
  • 2018-01-25 still printing while writing this Thing
  • 2018-01-26 also uploaded a script to generate the map on the outside of the sphere

author: JJNiko

description.text:
WARNING: This is one of my first 3D Designs. it is dependent on the PSU size which can vary, you might need somepost-printing adjustments to assemble the levels depending on your printer's accuracy and the top cover should be a little bit higher to avoid pressing the Razberry button.
.
Goal:
I use Domoticz for my home automation with the following hardware :

  • Raspberry Pi 3 (more current, but I can take it anywhere to include new devices)
    , Z-Wave.me Razberry daughter card
  • RFX433trx
  • MySensors Ethernet Gateway
  • Raspberry UPS on LiPo (not for power failure, but I can take it anywhere to include new devices without halt-unplug-plug-boot cycle)
    . Generic 5V/4A power supply (standard adapters are not powerful enough)
  • SDCard protected, but still accessible without unscrewing

I wanted to be able to unplug the server to bring it with me, close to the device to include without halting, unpluging, plugging again, booting and initializing. I chose a Raspberry 3 for the Wifi chipset and to avoid the need for an ethernet plug. I chose to have an UPS included in the server.
I wanted to have a design isolating the high voltage from the low voltage parts, in separate cells, with a switch for the high voltage input and a switch for the UPS.
I wanted passive cooling, I added heat sinks to the raspberry and a lot of holes to the case. The hole position is chosen to leverage the natural convection air flow, and to keep the high voltage (heat generator) isolated from the low voltage case.
I wanted something as compact as possible, I chose to keep the MySensors gateway connected with ethernet, I can place it at the best radio position and communicate with the server by Ethernet+Wifi. Regarding the RFX433trx, I did not want to unmount it or to split the USB power from the USB data, so, I choose to keep it apart as an external add-on.
I hate to remove supports from my printings... I wanted a supportless design.
Basically, the server includes the core (Power supply, UPS, Raspberry and ZWave shield, everthing else is optional (RFX and MySensors)

description.text:
Support for projector unic uc40, I do not know if it will also be for uc46.

The support consists of two parts, one that goes to the ceiling and another to the projector, are joined with a screw and nut to adjust the angle of inclination.

The ceiling support has six holes to screw the ceiling, with three is enough in the form of a triangle, also with them you can play to center the screen.

It also has a ring designed to hold cables and that these do not decenten the projector with its weight.

the part of the projector is embedded in the rear edge and in the leveling screw of the projector, these grips are sufficient for good stability.

I have corrected some errors that I have found after my printing for you.

I hope it serves you and is very useful.

The fixation I made it to the ceiling with 3 6mm studs and 3 screws.

title: Printrbot Play E3D V6 Adapter Plate and Cooling Fan Mount V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is inspired by the Printrbot simple adapter plate, your commonplace groovemount, and my need for a place for a cooling fan.

Version 2 of my last e3d v6 upgrade. The v6 now sits completely outside of the printrbot extruder which makes it waaaaaay easier to install and adds the extra height to clear the backblate without placing bets on it. Also added the nema spacer, extruder spacer/filament guide, and a fan shroud.

Note: not completely tested yet.. good luck!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Play

Infill:

Something reasonable >30%

Installation

Spacers

  1. Remove the extruder from the printer.
  2. Install the hot end spacer into the extruder.
  3. Shove your PTFE tube into the V6
  4. Push the PTFE up into the hot end spacer
  5. Cut the PTFE a little.
  6. Repeat until the PTFE reaches all the way up through the hot end spacer and is flush against the extruder AND the V6 heatsink is flush with the hot end spacer below.
  7. Add the NEMA spacer between the extruder and the stepper.
  8. Readjust the hobbed gear forward if required
  9. Smash the extruder and stepper back together.

Cooling Fan

  1. Sandwich the fan mount arm between the cooling fan and the shroud
  2. Zip-tie that sh-t together like a professional

Hot End

  1. Pop 2 M3 screws into the mount back
  2. Press 2 M3 nuts into the back of the mount back
  3. Screw the hot end into the bottom half of the extruder with the fan mount on the left-hand side (viewing from the front)
  4. Add 2 M3 screws to the mount front
  5. Mount your V6 into the mount groove and lock it into place by screwing the mount front into the mount back. Make sure your PTFE tube goes up into the hot end spacer.
  6. Clamp the V6 into place by screwing the mount front into the mount back.
  7. Freak out if the mount prevents the carriage hitting the X endstop. I don't think it should do it anymore with some changes, but it might.
Designed in OnShape. It's public! Go mess with it!

title: Long Slot Post for Sixth-Finger / Sixth-Toe Capacitive Stylus

description.text:
This remix is strictly to take advantage of a 15 mm long coupling nut that I found on Amazon (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00Z3XE5ZA). The longer nut requires a longer slot be cut in the post (yellow post in picture) but it also means that, for the same length post, a shorter bolt can be used - between 5 and 8 mm shorter). A shorter bolt may be easier to insert into a small diameter ring.

As with the original design, you should only download the zipx file. The STL file is included just for visualization purposes. And, as with the original design, all assembly instructions can be found here: https://wp.me/P9evBA-25

title: Small hand file set holder for pegboard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I would love to tell you what file set this is, but I have no idea where I got it. It's a small set of hand files - not quite needle files but certainly not "standard" size - that I've had for a little while and use quite often, so I made this holder. The recesses are sized for the rectangular guards on the handle so this might work for other files but it definitely works nicely for these.

I listed the pegboard 2 position blank as a source but I had trouble using the geometry cleanly in SketchUp so I wound up just using the profile of one of the top pegs and re-extruding - but hey, credit where credit is due, it's a good design that saved me time.

Other items visible in the photos:

  • Pegboard screwdriver funnel
  • Pegboard plier holder
  • Samsung Galaxy S3 dock for pegboard
    (Now holding my old Moto X as the GS3 died)

description.text: Three 28mm Bar Tables for Shadowrun or modern rpgs. One table is empty, the second has one place serving, and the third has two place servings (for variety in layout). Designed to be used with the 28mm Coffee Bar.

Design organically shaped vases with this customizer. The designs are simply comprised of one or two tapered spirals, each of which is in turn comprised of a series of overlapping spheres.  
You control the basic shape by setting the size and position of the first and last nodes (spheres). Then the customizer interpolates the specified number of steps along that spiral path. I hope the attached diagram helps explain the basic settings.  
If you enable "pair mode", you get two instances of the basic spiral shape. Customize their relative position and orientation to create interesting conjoined forms.
Intended to be printed with zero infill and zero top layers (or, just stop your printer around 90%).
Part of my Customizable Containers series.

I printed the spiral-node-hips.stl sample file in brown PLA on my Printrbot Simple. 0.15 mm layer height, 3 walls, 8 bottom layers, no top layers and no infill. I printed the spiral-node-split-s.stl sample file the same way.
